reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s “multiplicative/independent factors” move used to motivate eutopian fragility and the rarity of mostly-great futures. That move is an important intuitive pillar (and explicitly framed as a model of why single flaws can erase a lot of value), but it is not the sole support for the overall ‘no easy eutopia’ conclusion, which also relies on broader arguments about fussy moral views, scale, boundedness, and goods/bads aggregation. Hence moderate centrality. The objection is substantively forceful: if key dimensions are positively correlated via shared institutions/competence, the independent-uniform product toy model overstates skew and rarity, and the authors would need a robustness argument under plausible correlation structures. However, it only partially refutes the pivot because (i) the essay presents the product model as a toy/illustrative model rather than a fully defended empirical independence claim, (ii) positive correlation need not remove fragility unless very strong, and (iii) some dimensions could be weakly correlated or even negatively coupled, so the critique doesn’t establish that “mostly-great” futures become common—only that the toy-model inference is not yet justified. Most statements in the critique are correct, with some overreach in implying the broader ‘fragility ⇒ narrow target’ inference “stops following” full stop (it stops following from that toy independence case, but other routes remain). The critique is clear, focused, and has little dead weight.
title: Positive institutional correlations undermine the product-model claim that near-eutopia is rare
